questions.text: As urine flow increases during osmotic diuresis, the osmolality ____?
questions.solution:
• Normal urine osmolarity is higher than plasma (plasma normal osmolality is around 290 mosm/kg).
  • Osmotic diuresis is a condition where an increased amount of urine is produced due to the presence of certain substances (not absorbed efficiently) in the fluid filtered by the kidneys.
  • As the osmotic diuresis occurs the plasma that is filtered through bowman membrane is increased.
  • The major portion remained in the tubule will be from the proximal tubule, where the fluid is isotonic.
  • Whatever the fluid is filtered the fixed fraction is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. So fluid filtered increases means more fluid travel further to the other segments and excreted with near plasma osmolarity.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1587

questions.text: Among the following hormone which hormone acts through intracellular receptors?
questions.solution:
• In the above list parathyroid hormone is a peptide hormone. It acts through cyclic AMP second messenger system. It can-not enter the cell so it binds to surface receptors for its mechanism of action.
  • Estrogen hormone, can directly enter inside the cell. It is made from cholesterol. It can enter easily in the cell, so acts through intracellular receptors.
  • GH acts via membrane receptor that phosphorylates and activates JAK2, which in turn phosphorylates STAT proteins. It is peptide hormone.
  • ACTH is peptide hormone secreted from anterior pituitary gland cAMP second messenger system.

questions.text: Proopiomelanocortin is a prohormone synthesized by corticotropes in the anterior lobe of pituitary gland. It is also synthesized in?
questions.solution:
• Proopiomelanocortin is a prohormone synthesized from anterior lobe or intermediate lobe of pituitary gland.
  • It is also synthesized from hypothalamus, lungs, placenta and also from gastrointestinal tract.
  • It is a precursor of ACTH. When hydrolyzed it forms ACTH, beta lipoprotein, beta endorphin.
  • In intermediate lobe it also forms corticotropin like intermediate lobe peptide.
  • ACTH increases the secretion of adrenocortical hormones.
  • Adrenal cortex secretes glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids and sex steroids.
  • Posterior lobe of pituitary gland secretes oxytocin and vasopressin hormone.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 736, 952, 1121

questions.text: A 31-year-old female was suspected to have thyroid disorder. On visit the endocrinologist prescribed her some tests. her thyroxine binding globulin levels are increased. Which of the following probably would cause it?
questions.solution:
• TBG levels are elevated in estrogen-treated patients and during pregnancy, as well as after treatment with methadone, heroin, antipsychotic drug, estrogen etc.
  • TBG levels are depressed by androgens, danazol, glucocorticoids, Chemotherapy (L-asparginase)
  • Similar changes mimicking decrease in TBG level are seen in salicylates, phenytoin, 5-fluorouracil etc.
  • When a sudden, sustained increase in the concentration of thyroid-binding proteins in the plasma takes place, the concentration of free thyroid hormones falls. Opposite changes are seen with decrease in conc. Of TBG.
  • These above changes are temporary. As it will lead to change in TSH level followed by change in free thyroid hormone level.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 839 Table 20-2

questions.text: There are many glucose transporters present in different cells of the body for entry of glucose. Fructose transport occurs by which of the following GLUT ?
questions.solution:
• The GLUTs that are responsible for facilitated diffusion of glucose across cell membranes.
  • There are various glucose transporters present in different cells of the body. Some transporters are known as GLUTs (facilitated diffusion). Some transporters transport glucose by secondary active transport (SGLT).
  • GLUT 5 is present in jejunum & sperm. It is responsible for fructose transport.
  • In Muscle (GLUT 4) & in adipose tissue (GLUT 4) are present. These transporters are insulin sensitive. Insulin causes rapid uptake, storage & use of glucose.
  • In liver there is GLUT 2.
  • Nervous tissue, kidney, RBC, retina, blood vessels & intestinal mucosa (GLUT 1, GLUT 3) - are not dependent on insulin for glucose transport.
  • GLUT 7 is present in liver. Glucose 6 phosphate transporter in endoplasmic reticulum.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 996 table 24-3

questions.text: Amenorrhea (Missing of one or more menstrual period) is seen in?
questions.solution:
• Amenorrhoea is absence of menstruation.
  • It can be primary or secondary
  • Primary amenorrhea is menstruation never ever has occurred in female.
  • Secondary amenorrhea is Cessation of cycles in a woman with previously normal periods.
  • Pregnancy is the physiological cause of secondary amenorrhea. It is due to high estrogen and progesterone level.
  • Hyperprolactinemia causes amenorrhea as it inhibit the secretion of GnRH. Due to this FSH and LH and ultimately estrogen and progesterone are decreased causing amenorrhea.
  • Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder in which patient eat very less. Patient is having least amount of fat. So leptin is less.
  • Normal Leptin has relation with the normal menstruation. Its deficiency produces amenorrhea.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 914, 915

questions.text: Among the following list function of Sertoli cell is?
questions.solution:
Functions of sertoli cells:

  • Physical support, nutrition, and removal of waste products to maturing germ cells
  • Phagocytic function of residual bodies during Spermatogenesis.
  • Maintenance of blood testes barrier
    • Tight junctions limits transport of substances from blood to lumen of seminiferous tubules
    • Mature sperm cells are very immunogenic so prevents it from the action of antibodies
  • Secretary functions
    • Mullerian inhibitory substance
    • Inhibin
    • Androgen binding protein
    • Oestrogen
    • Transport proteins (ceruloplasmin and transferrin)
    • Plasminogen activator (Proteolytic to disrupt tight junction)
    • Tubular fluid secretion rich in K+ and HCO3-

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 965-967

questions.text:
Recognize the sequence of development of female characteristic during puberty.
1. Menarche
2. Thelarche
3. Pubarche
questions.solution:
• Development of breasts is known as thelarche.
  • Development of axillary and pubic hair is known as pubarche.
  • First period of menstruation is known as menarche. Initial menstrual periods are generally an ovulatory, and regular ovulation appears about a year later.
  • The sequence of event occurs from thelarche to pubarche and menarche at the time of puberty.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male has low gonadotropin levels. There is partial loss of sense of smell. On investigation there is mutation in the Y chromosome. Diagnosis in this patient is?
questions.solution:
• Kallmann syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (low gonadotropin levels) and anosmia or hyposmia (complete or partial loss of the sense of smell).
    • This occurs due to the failure of the olfactory neurons and gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) neurons to properly migrate from the olfactory placode to the hypothalamus during embryonic development.
  • Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is a chromosomal disorder characterized by an extra X chromosome in males, leading to hypogonadism, small testes, reduced fertility, and sometimes cognitive impairments.
    • Gonadotropin level is high in patients.
  • AIS is a condition where an individual is genetically male (46, XY) but has a partial or complete inability to respond to androgens due to mutations in the androgen receptor gene.
    • There is no anosmia in this patient.
  • Turner syndrome (45, X or mosaic 45,X/46,XY) is a condition that affects females, characterized by the partial or complete absence of one X chromosome.
    • It presents with short stature, gonadal dysgenesis, and various congenital abnormalities. It does not apply to a male patient or present with a mutation on the Y chromosome, nor does it cause a partial loss of the sense of smell.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 719, 720

questions.text: Which of the following factor increases secretion of growth hormone?
questions.solution:
• Following is the list of factors affecting secretion of growth hormone.
  • GH is a counter-regulatory hormone that helps to increase blood glucose levels by stimulating gluconeogenesis in the liver and reducing peripheral glucose uptake.
  • IGF-1, mainly produced in the liver in response to GH, provides negative feedback to the hypothalamus and pituitary gland to inhibit GH secretion.
  • Adequate levels of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are necessary for normal GH production and release. Hypothyroidism can impair the function of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, leading to decreased GH secretion.
  • Increased body fat, particularly visceral fat, is linked to lower GH release due to elevated levels of free fatty acids, insulin resistance, and higher circulating levels of somatostatin (growth hormone-inhibiting hormone).

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 740 Table 18-2

questions.text: Activation of V1B receptors (vasopressin) stimulates the following action?
questions.solution:
• Vasopressin receptors are of two types
    • V1 (V1A and V1B)
    • V2 receptors
  • The V1B receptors are located in the anterior pituitary gland. When vasopressin binds to V1B receptors, it stimulates the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the corticotrope cells. Increased ACTH secretion subsequently stimulates the adrenal cortex to produce cortisol, which plays a key role in the body's response to stress.
  • The V1A receptors, located on vascular smooth muscle cells, when activated by vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone, ADH), cause vasoconstriction, leading to an increase in systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure.
  • Vasopressin binds to V2 receptors located on the cells of the renal collecting ducts, leading to the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the cell membrane, which increases water reabsorption back into the bloodstream, thus concentrating the urine.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 711, 1600

questions.text: Which of the following factor inhibit the expression of NaPi-IIc to reduce the level of 1,25dihydrtoxycholecalciferol?
questions.solution:
• Alpha-Klotho is a co-receptor that enhances the activity of fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF-23). While it is involved in phosphate metabolism and vitamin D regulation,
    • It functions by forming a complex with FGF-23 to increase its activity, which indirectly affects phosphate regulation and 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol levels.
    • Alpha-Klotho itself does not directly inhibit the expression of NaPi-IIc Fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) decreases renal NaPi-IIa and NaPi-IIc expression and inhibits the production of 1α-hydroxylase, reducing levels of 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol.
    • It acts by decreasing the expression of sodium-phosphate cotransporters
  • Calcitonin is a hormone which reduces the blood calcium level by depositing the calcium level in the bone.
    • It does not specifically inhibit the expression of NaPi-IIc.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 870

questions.text: Inulin (para amino hippuric acid) is useful to measure which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Inulin is the gold standard for measuring glomerular filtration rate (GFR) because it is freely filtered by the glomeruli and is neither reabsorbed, secreted, metabolized, nor synthesized by the kidneys.
    • This property makes inulin an ideal substance for accurately determining GFR, as its concentration in the urine reflects the amount filtered by the glomeruli.
  • The substance which is freely filtered not reabsorbed but secreted in the tubules is useful to measure renal plasma flow. Renal plasma flow (RPF) equals the amount of a substance excreted per unit of time divided by the renal arteriovenous difference.
    • PAH is the substance used to measure RPF.
  • The excretion rate:- It is the amount of a substance that appears in the urine per unit time.
    • Excretion rate= urine flow rate (V) × urine concentration of the substance (Ux)

The excretion rate is a more general term that does not indicate the specific use of inulin for GFR measurement or PAH for RPF measurement.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition page number. 1545
